metadata.titleEn: Fluid data set of rongna deposit, Tibet, China (~118 Ma)
metadata.description: 1) The data set includes fluid isotope data, homogenization temperature and salinity of inclusions, and in-situ LA-ICPMS composition data of the Rongna deposit, Tibet; 2) The data come from authoritative laboratories at home and abroad; 3) The data quality meets the standard; 4) Based on this data, the fluid evolution process of the Rongna superlarge porphyry-high sulfidation epithermal deposit in Tibet is reconstructed. Especially, the transformation process of fluid from porphyry to high sulfidation epithermal transition is described. It is found that the copper mineralization of the high sulfidation style in the deposit may be related to the dissolution and reprecipitation of copper minerals formed during porphyry stage. It is expected to provide support for the deepening of metallogenic theory and mineral exploration prediction of porphyry metallogenic system in the future.

authorList.unitEn: Donghua University of Science and Technology

literatureList.titleEn: Porphyry to epithermal transition at the Rongna Cu-(Au) deposit, Tibet: Insights from H-O isotopes and fluid inclusion analysis
literatureList.referenceEn: Zhang, X.N., Li, G.M., Qin, K.Z., Lehmann, B., Li, J.X., Zhao, J.X. (2020). Porphyry to epithermal transition at the Rongna Cu-(Au) deposit, Tibet: Insights from H-O isotopes and fluid inclusion analysis. Ore Geology Reviews, 123, 103585.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to analyze fluid evolution in mineral deposits, specifically in relation to the transition from porphyry systems to high-sulfidation epithermal systems?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves utilizing fluid isotope data, homogenization temperature and salinity measurements of fluid inclusions, and in-situ LA-ICPMS compositional data from authoritative laboratories. This method allows researchers to reconstruct the fluid evolution process in mineral deposits, highlighting the transition from porphyry systems to high-sulfidation epithermal systems.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of fluid isotope data in datasets related to mineral deposits?
Feature Specification.Answer: isotopic composition data, homogenization temperature, salinity of fluid inclusions, in-situ LA-ICPMS compositional data

Definition.Question: What are the key components of a fluid isotope data collection method in geological research?
Definition.Answer: A fluid isotope data collection method in geological research includes collecting fluid isotope data, homogenization temperatures, salinity of inclusions, and in-situ LA-ICPMS compositional data. The data is obtained from authoritative laboratories, ensuring standard quality, and is used to reconstruct the fluid evolution process of geological formations, such as the transition from porphyry to high-sulfidation epithermal systems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of utilizing fluid isotopic data and in-situ LA-ICPMS compositional data on understanding the fluid evolution process in mineral deposits?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing fluid isotopic data and in-situ LA-ICPMS compositional data allows researchers to reconstruct the fluid evolution process of mineral deposits, particularly in understanding the transition of fluid types from porphyry systems to high-sulfidation epithermal systems. This approach provides insights into how high-sulfidation copper mineralization may be related to the dissolution and re-precipitation of copper minerals within the porphyry system, thus offering a foundation for revealing the genesis of porphyry-high sulfidation coupled deposits and potentially supporting advancements in ore-forming theories and mineral exploration predictions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting fluid isotope data, homogenization temperatures, salinity, and in-situ LA-ICPMS compositional data for understanding mineral deposit formations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to reconstruct the fluid evolution process of the giant porphyry-high-sulfidation epithermal deposit in the Rongna region of Tibet, particularly to characterize the transition from a porphyry system to a high-sulfidation epithermal system. This helps to provide insights into the genesis of porphyry-high-sulfidation coupled deposits and supports the advancement of mineralization theories and exploration predictions for porphyry mineralization systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific procedures and laboratory analyses utilized to obtain high-quality fluid isotope data and in-situ LA-ICPMS compositional data for studying the fluid evolution in porphyry-high sulfidation epithermal systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves using analyses from authoritative domestic and international laboratories to ensure data quality. The procedures include obtaining fluid isotope data, homogenization temperatures, and salinities from fluid inclusions, as well as in-situ LA-ICPMS compositional data. These methods help in reconstructing the fluid evolution process from porphyry to high sulfidation epithermal systems and understanding the role of copper mineral dissolution and reprecipitation in the high sulfidation system.
